awd_titl_txt: Investigating the effects of sediment supply, width variation, and unsteady flow on riffle-pool dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Many gravel-bedded rivers feature quasi-regular alternations of deep and shallow zones known as riffle-pool sequences, which, in straight sections of the river, are often influenced by variations in channel width. These zones provide an important diversity of habitats, and the reestablishment of riffle-pool sequences can be a desired outcome of river restoration projects. How pool-riffle sequences persist is a century-old question in geomorphology that is still not fully resolved, and there is currently a lack of field-based, theoretical, or experimental studies that explore the relationship between unsteady flow, sediment supply, sorting, and riffle-pool morphology. This study aims to fill this gap through numerical modeling, flume experiments, and field observations.  The project will train a graduate student, engage several undergraduate students in supervised independent research projects, and incorporate activities into undergraduate and graduate classes in river mechanics and sediment transport. Improvements made to the computer model will be incorporated into freely-available software package so that findings from this study can be applied to other settings for a wide range of scientific questions.

A two-dimensional morphodynamic model will be used to explore how river channel width variations, hydrograph shapes, and changes in sediment supply influence equilibrium patterns of topography and bed-surface sorting. Model results will guide mobile-bed, mixed-grain-size experiments conducted in a variable-width flume. Experimental runs under constant discharge and repeat hydrographs will provide insight on the effects of unsteady flow on riffle-pool dynamics, and experimental runs with decreased and increased sediment supply will investigate how riffles and pools might be affected by dam installation or dam removal. The laboratory-scale simulations and experiments will be complemented with data collected from a riffle-pool sequence on the Elwha River, Washington, USA, where an ongoing dam removal project has created a natural experiment in which the river is subject to a greatly increased sediment supply.

por.por_cntn:
Many gravel-bed rivers feature quasi-regular alternations of deep and shallow areas known as riffle-pool sequences, which in straight reaches are often forced by variations in channel width. These areas provide an important diversity of habitats, and the reestablishment of riffle-pool sequences can be a desired outcome of river restoration projects. In this project, we performed flume experiments, developed and used numerical models, and collected field data to improve our understanding of how the morphodynamics of riffle-pool sequences are affected by unsteady flow and changes in sediment supply.

 

Our one- and two-dimensional numerical morphodynamic model simulations showed that the amplitude and wavelength of downstream variations in channel width is an important control on how much topographic relief occurs between riffles and pools, as well as whether wide portions of the channel develop bars near the banks or in the center of the channel. Simulations in which sediment pulses were added to the channel allowed us to quantify how these pulses evolve over time, and how that evolution is influenced by pulse size, duration, and grain size. Understanding the evolution and dynamics of sediment pulses is increasingly important, as wildfires (which can cause sudden large introductions of sediment to river channels) become more frequent, and as dam removals become more common.

 

Flume experiments were conducted in a straight-walled channel and one with downstream variations in width. During the experiments, we explored the morphodynamic effects of hydrographs and changes in sediment supply. When the sediment supplied to the flumes was doubled from an equilibrium condition, the straight channel?s primary response was to steepen, while the variable-width channel was able to reduce the riffle-pool relief and cross-sectional elevation variability. Our experiments also developed alternate bars under conditions that current analytical theory would not predict their occurrence, suggesting that we potentially need to develop improved theories for this phenomenon. We relied on the relatively new technique of structure-from-motion (SfM) to characterize the bed topography during these experiments, and we have published a paper that provides guidance for using these methods in laboratory flume experiments.

 

Over three field seasons, we collected topographic, bathymetric, and grain size data on a reach of the Elwha River in Washington State downstream of the former Glines Canyon Dam, which was removed just before the start of this project. These data, along with analysis of aerial imagery dating back to 1939, suggest that rates of both widening and meander migration have increased following dam removal. Our results, which indicate an increased dynamism due directly to the amplified sediment supply, have the potential to further inform river managers and restoration specialists who oversee projects related to changing sediment regimes.

 

Findings from this project have been presented at several international conferences, and they have been and will continue to be published in peer-reviewed journals. The project supported the training of two graduate students and several undergraduate students. We also have performed demonstrations of sediment pulse dynamics in a small flume to several high school groups that have visited the CSU hydraulics laboratory. These student groups are largely underrepresented in the sciences, as they came from low-income urban schools in the Denver area, or schools that primarily serve Native Americans or other minority groups from different parts of Colorado. Our hope is to spark interest in science in these students at a young age, so that they are aware of possible academic and professional opportunities related to river science.
